title: What will be the Estimated CO2 (carbon dioxide) Daily Global Seasonal Cycle value for 1 December 2020, according to NOAA's Earth System Research Laboratory?
possible_answers: More than 414.00 ppm but less than 416.00 ppm
correct_answer: More than 414.00 ppm but less than 416.00 ppm
preds: It will rise above 414 today, and because these values are output from a model that smooths observations, it will not decline again until next spring.

Currently the value sits at 413.94 in the cycle column and has been increasing by 0.04 ppm for the last week. This combined with the delta combined to last years makes it likely that it will be above 414.00 ppm

Levels of carbon dioxide, a product of burning fossil fuels that is the biggest contributor to global warming, touched a new record of 410.5 parts per million in 2019, it said. The annual increase is larger than the previous year and beats the average over the last decade. “Such a rate of increase has never been seen in the history of our records,” WMO Secretary-General Professor Petteri Taalas said, referring to rises since 2015, calling for a “sustained flattening of the (emissions) curve.” Global data is not yet available for 2020 but the trend of rising concentrations appears to be intact, the WMO said, citing initial readings from its Tasmania and Hawaii stations.

I looked at last years value which was 411.41 ppm.
I then compared the amount by which a value increased from the previous year and was able to create distributions, which are generally in the range of 2-3 ppm per year. Then  I created 3 predictions and averaged them:
-1 randomly sample from the change values for the last 365 days and see how many of those would make the December 1 value fall between 414 and 416. (50.25% chance)
-2 randomly sample from the change values of the last 30 days (90% chance)
-3 randomly sample from the change values of the last 7 days (100% chance) I decided to take the median value then.

NOAA seem to be constantly revising upwards, so as of now, the next 22 days need to average a rise of only 0.035 to reach 414.  Over the last few previous years daily integers have dipped to 0.03 for just a few days before rising back to 0.04. Unless we experience a rogue 11 day trough at 0.03ppm per day or a shorter trough where the daily growth integer dips to 0.02, est ppm on Dec 1st will be 414 or above.

On the other hand though I took a look at September and October 1st, and September 1st is on trend but October 1st is over trend. But looking at the October 1st to December 1st gain each year, the years where October 1st is over trend appear to have lower gains from October to December. I'm thinking the data is a bit noisy and the trend is probably the most reliable. I decided to switch again, reading about the new report by UN/WMO and its painting rather pessimistic picture of the situation just this morning is the trigger (haven't had time to look at the report itself).
One of the key findings is that the pandemic effect exists (reduction of CO2 emissions due to temporarily reduced economic activity), but it will not last and will be smallish.
https://public.wmo.int/en/resources/united_in_science The CA wildfires now count 44 most of them far from contained and very large, and the season is so extraordinary and will likely go far into October this year that I expect this cannot be without any effect on the total CO2 balance, as burning forests have a twofold effect. Not only will additional CO2 be set free, but also the capacity of sinking CO2 for the future is then reduced. Just by a flight of fancy, there may be even a statistical side effect and distortion based on the relative geographical proximity of CA and the NOAA's observatory on Hawaii (at least one of the four stations mentioned in the source): 
"The estimated daily global seasonal cycle and trend value for CO2 are determined from the daily averaged CO2 data from the four NOAA/ESRL/GMD Baseline observatories." Mauna Loa, Hawaii must be one of them, maybe even Barrow, Alaska will early detect a raised CO2 concentration due to the CA wildfires in the next weeks. The other two are obviously in American Samoa and on South Pole, Antarctica. 
According to my understanding of physical processes like diffusion, the additional CO2 from wildfires will not be immediately spread evenly across the global atmosphere but the highest concentrations will be observed in the place of origin, of course, an then will reduce correlated to the squared (or cubic?) distance to origin. So at least one of four observatories may observe a temporary significant shift upwards that creates noise which is hard to be corrected for.
The same effect was obviously noticed in the Boulder aerosol measurements in Boulder, CO, as the ESRL published
https://www.esrl.noaa.gov/gmd/smoke.html The website
https://www.esrl.noaa.gov/gmd/ may provide useful info and further reading, resources and news on this question's topic, such as: https://www.esrl.noaa.gov/gmd/ccgg/trends/ https://www.esrl.noaa.gov/gmd/ccgg/
(that's probably where the source .txt-file is linked from) https://www.esrl.noaa.gov/gmd/ccgg/covid2.html Just by chance I stumbled upon the ESRL's "Rapid Refresh" resources. Concerning the duration of the wildfires, there's hardly any hope for it to end soon by the assistance of rainfalls, as the relative humidity in the 850hPa surface shows:
https://rapidrefresh.noaa.gov/displayImage.cgi?image=rh850image&width=806&model=rr&title=RAP
The whole west coast, large areas of the Pacific offshore, shows extremely dry air with relative humidity of 20% or less (maybe even caused by the fires themselves...) I'll have to go through all of this in time, for now it seems to be wise to be on the higher end of scale. EDIT: Maybe I've found the solution for myself by just reducing complexity (focusing on the Mauna Loa/HI data, and with the help of this interactive plot: https://www.esrl.noaa.gov/gmd/ccgg/trends/graph.html Trend for August 2020 is 414.48ppm for this observatory alone.
Comparison of the "November 2019" value (which may be either a monthly average or the 30 Nov 2019-value) with the global value (cyclical and trend) of 30 Nov 2019 in the .txt-file 
"co2: 410.25" and "trend:412.26" versus 411.37 and 411.27 (as retrieved on 13 September 2020/reported on 12 Sep 2020)
shows that 
/first, by the time of the question's resolution, global cyclical and  trend value tend to be almost identical, while the cyclical value (the one that resolves the question) is still likely to be slightly higher by .1ppm
/second, the Mauna Loa,HI "trend" value tends to be roughly 1.00ppm higher than the global value. Then, approximation of growth from today's values to 01 Dec 2020 can be done by retrieving the Mauna Loa, HI values of August 2019
"co2: 409.95" and "trend: 411.87".
So over the three months Sep, Oct, Nov 2019 the trend grew by 0.39ppm Adding this to latest August 2020 "trend" value of 414.48ppm but deducting from it the 1.00ppm by which Mauna Loa, HI tops the global value, I receive 413.85ppm.
Adding the .1ppm by which the global cyclical value tops the trend in the November stats, I receive 413.95ppm.
I wonder if it has an impact on that approximation that we're not at any month's end right now, but don't think so.

(cycle top 04-11 May 2011: 392.26 The June equitable value (ev) is jumping but there was a tendency to be 2 or 3 days later in 2017/18 than in 2016. For the 2019 season the June ev sank, probably because of a warmer than average spring and an earlier than average beginning of the growing period in the northern hemisphere. 2020 June ev was in May actually, as this year's traffic emissions have been extraordinarily low, as the 2020 values may be exceptional as a whole! Jul evs of the following year (e.g. 14 Jul 2018 for 2017 season) tend to be ever later and will have shifted this year by 2 to 3 days to est. 15 Jul 2020 for 2019 season. This shift indicates that total emissions are still growing yoy, even though traffic with it's less than 20% share in total emissions globally will have been cut in half in 2020. Two sources of emissions at the moment will (over-)compensate for the reductions in traffic:
Wildfires in the amazon region are at their worst extension in the last decade.
And, maybe even more important, permafrost grounds in northern Siberia are currently melting with temperatures at above 30°C in some places, more than 20K above what is normal. This sets free large amounts of methane that will migrate to higher strata of the atmosphere, where the molecules have a lifetime of about 90 days (causing a strong greenhouse effect) and then dissolve into H2O and CO2 probably. Wildfires in Siberia have led to an emission of 59 megatons of CO2 in the past 18 months, more than in the 16 years before combined. I think gas production will have released considerable amounts of natural gas (methane, ethane) into the air, as production of gas seems hard to regulate down, while heating consumption was low in Europe during winter 2019/20 and industrial demand and consumption will have crashed in Q1 and the first half of Q2 2020. Global deforestation makes it increasingly difficult for biomass to bind the carbon in carbon(di)oxide and to recycle CO2 to O2, and oceans have warmed, and saturated and soured to an extent that oceans will no longer absorb but rather release additional CO2. In all, I expect a 01 Dec 2020-value that is in line with the four year-trend and will lie only ~0.4ppm below previous (2019) season's maximum 26 Apr - 04 May 2020 of 414.53, at est. 414.11ppm CO2.

I am going to elaborate my approach and forecast done in [3]. The data to be used for the resolution of this question are unusual.  Instead of raw measurements, average smoothed data are used. CO2 measurements, as in most geophysical data, are rather noisy.  For stable estimates, scientists are not interested in the noise in the data and came up with various ways to smooth the measurements and remove the noise.  According to the headers in the Global Trends in CO2 dataset [1], the “cycle” data column (which determines the outcome of the forecast) comes from averaging four “smoothed” datasets. Each dataset is least squares fitted to a long-term trend (a second order polynomial) and annual oscillations (4 yearly harmonics).  The residuals from the smoothed fitting is low-passed filtered to remove short term variability (i.e. 50-day or shorter variations are removed).  The filtered residuals are added back to the long-term trend and annual oscillation curves [2].  Finally the 4 “smoothed” datasets are averaged and put as the “cycle” column of the Global Trends in CO2 dataset [1]. Both the long-term trend and annual oscillations in the data are rather stable over time.  The long-term trend represents the increasing in CO2 over time. Despite of the various international calls for the reduction of greenhouse gases, it does not change (especially flattening) much over the years.  The annual oscillations are driven by biology, chemistry and physics, associated with seasonal variations in human energy usage, vegetation growth and decay, etc.  They, too, are stable over the years unless there are some large scale catastrophic events. When the 10-year averaged smoothed data are curve-fitted using the same curve-fitting methodology as the data, the residuals represent local variations of CO2 measurements.  Since we are only interested in the global long-term values, deviations from the fitted curve are treated as random noise.  The scheme that I used is to use the fitted curve to predict the future (~300 days in the future) value and use the residuals to determine the error (and probabilities) of the prediction.
The underlying assumption in this approach is the fitted curve is almost perfect (see consistence check below) in predicting values ~300 day in the future, and errors in the prediction are random errors.  In my previous forecast [3], the random errors are assumption to be Gaussian.  In this forecast update, the actual empirical probability distribution is used instead since I found that the distribution.  The probabilities are not that different from the Gaussian case.   As a consistence check, I have curve fitted the data using various lengths of time (6 to 9 years) and use the fitted curves to predict 300 days in the future.  Then I compared the prediction is the data.  Below are the results (prediction, data and difference).  The maximum prediction error is slightly above 0.2%. 
9 years: 412.0, 411.4, 0.61
8 years: 409.7, 408.9, 0.83
7 years: 407.0, 406.4, 0.59
6 years: 403.4, 404.2, -0.78 [1]  https://www.esrl.noaa.gov/gmd/ccgg/trends/gl_data.html
[2]  https://www.esrl.noaa.gov/gmd/ccgg/mbl/crvfit/crvfit.html
[3]  https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/943341

Among the inputs my forecast is based on (ARIMA, ETS, UK Met office forecast on natural sinks), I am also incorporating @jtrommel's model results based on an STL approach.

I checked an STL-model using the historical record. The STL-predictions seem to be very robust, if slightly (on average -0.2 ppm) underestimating the observed value at December 1st. The seasonal pattern is very stable and the seasonally adjusted component is approximated with the Loess-method. This can cause the trend line to "wobble" a bit when new data become available and we get closer to the prediction date. This is the case with these data and in general the result is that when the CO2-value drops after the month of May, the STL-model tends to underpredict the value for December 1st. On average this is 0.2 ppm, so this is not critical given that the differences between the levels is 2 ppm. At present (2020-01-25)  the prediction is 414.6 ppm with a sigma of 0.166 ppm. The region 414-416 seems the most likely.

~~~ 
Digest
~~~ An Inside View argument suggests the 3rd bucket should be increased but the key question is how much to increase it without resorting to subjective adjustments that are prone to be biased. ~~~
Analysis
~~~ Following previous methods: ARIMA [1] and ETS [2], I adjust for the Inside View based on projections by the UK Met Office [3] The Met Office says that natural sinks are expected to be weaker this year, suggesting that CO2 concentrations *may* rise more than they typically do. "This year, the Met forecasts that the impact of weather patterns on global ecosystems will increase the annual human-caused rise in CO2 concentration by 10%, with emissions from the Australian fires accounting for one-fifth of that increase." We have to recognize that this does mean that the Met Office is forecasting the rise in CO2 concentration will be 10% bigger. The Met Office is not accounting for other big variable, namely, global CO2 emissions. For now I assume emission changes are not different from previous years. The key question is how do we properly estimate the probability of the second bucket without resorting to subjective changes. I take the average point forecast of my two models [1] and [2] which is 414.4 and shift the error distribution estimated by my first model [1] by 10%*[414.4 minus the value from Dec 1 2019]. The pattern of CO2 measurements around the globe show basically a combination of three signals; a long-term trend, a non-sinusoidal yearly cycle (note the yearly cycle is non-sinusoidal), and short term variations that can last from several hours to several weeks, which are due to local and regional influences.  It has been shown that a second-degree polynomial plus 4 yearly harmonics model the long-term and seasonal variation of CO2 pretty well (1).  I implemented this model and perform a least squares regression using the available data from NOAA (2).  Implementation of the model is straightforward if you use the matrix approach. I used the fitted model parameters to forecast the CO2 concentration on Dec 1, 2020 (about 334 days after the end of the data).  The forecast for CO2 concentration for Dec 1, 2020 is 414.45 with a root-mean-square error of 0.34.  From these, I estimate the probabilities 27% in bin 2, 72% in bin 3 and 1% in bin 4. There has been a trend for carbon dioxide levels to increase by at least 2 ppm for th last 7 years. 1st bucket has been eliminated.  This is the seventh consecutive year in which steep increases in ppm have been recorded, well above the previous average, and the fifth year since the 400ppm threshold was breached in 2014. As it was commented before, approaching this question statically makes sense. You have to appreciate the use of python and C by @Emil and @Petequinn - beautiful :).  I had a similar approach using the data provided by https://www.esrl.noaa.gov/gmd/ccgg/trends/global.html - the actual csv's I worked with I have downloaded via https://datahub.io/core/co2-ppm from which I used the actual mean levels per year each Nov: co2-annmean-mlo as well as the anual increase co2-gr-mlo. I haven't trusted the uncertainty level initially embedded in co2-gr-mlo so I have calculated it on my own. The graphs I worked with all used exponential growths, I never work with linear since it's simply not reliable or applicable in real-world scenarios. When you look at the global social trends, they are not linear (more on this on a paper I hope I will be able to publish this year, if I manage to finish it). Anyway, the point is using data up to 2017 I have made predictions by a mean increase of ~2.5 per year for 2018, 2019 and slightly increased it to ~2.6 for 2020 based on what my graph said.  Again, purely statistic, we're most likely going to see a value ~414.35 ppm in Dec 2020. Based only on that we should account a 90%+ chance to see an actual value between 414 and 416. But... there are a lot of variables at play here, thus the reason we can see high variations on an early basis, even though the trend is obvious (going up). Now for the forecast itself and the probabilities in it: 1. The reason I accounted a 20% probability for the value to be below the calculated prediction is that I have to take into account factors that are likely to contribute to lower CO2 emission levels. I'm not talking about EU's attempts to limit traffic, get more renewable energy produced and so on - it's a nice effort and I support it, but the impact takes too long to have an effect and at a global scale it's a drop in the CO2 ocean we're swimming (or breathing) in. What could get those levels significantly lower would be economic reasons that have an impact on the consumption of traditional fuels, a global recession that leads to job losses and factories being shut down, high oil prices leading to people having to use public transport instead of their private cars; a new beef related virus leading to a lot of them being dead or killed; etc.  You name it, but there are events that can lead to a lower CO2 emission and thus I had to integrate their cumulated probability in the forecast. 2. The reason I accounted a much higher probability (75%) of the value hitting the "target" 414 to 416 is... nothing's going to change that much in our behavior and thus we'll see another year with an increase in the CO2 emission rates. There's actually a good chance to go above a value close to 414 and see something above or equal to 415. We're seeing some help from the Australia fires, we might see another year with similar catastrophes in California, the fact we're heating up the climate doesn't help us lowering the CO2 emission levels. The population is going to grow following, again, an exponential growth and they are not going to turn vegan overnight – that means meat production will also go up, more animals, more CO2 emissions. Around the world, liberal economies are struggling to get the promised growth of a few percent each year, allowing more purchasing power for each individual consumer, allowing more people to buy cars, eat more and consume more energy (part of it being obtained from conventional fuels) – an increase of one leads to the increase of the other. We can think of a lot of scenarios where it is likely to see a lot of CO2 burned in the atmosphere, even a conflict having an effect on certain industries to power up their engines more. 3. A 5% chance to see a higher than 416ppm value. A reason for allocating those percents to a higher value can be found on points 1 and 2, but having a cumulated effect. We also need to remember's Taleb's favorite bird, the Black Swan, if we get such events, though their nature is unpredictable, one could argue they are likely to increase the emissions rather than lowering them. I find it hard to believe that before 2021 we'll get some alien technology that lower's the CO2 levels overnight or that algae that consume CO2 will spread around half of the worlds oceans. Imagining scenarios which lead to high CO2 values are more likely and easier to picture, hence reserving those percents here. The forecast is subject to changes based on what 2020 will reveal us.

One way to approach this is statistically since we have good data. Particularly suitable is time series modeling that extends past trend and seasonality to estimate future values. Specifically I use an autoregressive integrated moving average modeling with seasonality. This model requires a number of parameters, including if and how many past values to use, if and how many moving averages to use, etc. I used grid search to find the model with the lowest Akaike Information Criterion. There were a few configurations with a similar AIC so I chose one with fewer parameters.  I simplified the data by using only the first values of every month.  Result: Central prediction:

This is a tricky one, because our ability to predict won't improve as time draws closer. The data have strong annual variation. I've plotted the values for 1 December each year and then drawn a second order polynomial best fit (I started with linear and got R^2 ~ 0.983, then moved to the polynomial and got 0.999). I then used that best fit to project to 1 December 2020, and get a most likely value of 414.299. However, the variability between actual values and the best fit ranges between - 0.346 to + 0.372, and I get + 0.299 (the amount needed to get below 414.0) has a percentile rank of about 2.5%, which means a 3% probability, based on a naïve look at the data. Typing 4% in my forecast rather than 3 was a typo. @Emil @Anneinak @danielharan Thank you all for the suggestions. I've revised a bit and updated my predictions a bit. I now make my methods a little more clear.  I now use day, month, and year fixed effects. We have 365 data points a year over 10 years so we certainly have the degrees of freedom to do so. @Emil, all the point estimates are super precise. As @Anneinak points out, economic growth can play a big role in year over year changes. Per @danielharan's suggestion, I now report what my prediction method would have given as the prediction for 2011-2019 and what the actual value was. This may give a good sense of the errors on my prediction.  My prediction is comprised of three parts, the intercept, the year fixed effect prediction, and the monthly fixed effect. I compute the year fixed effect prediction by taking the previous years fixed effect and multiplying by (n+1)/n where n is the number of years in the sample.

Setting priors:
The most likely event that will have a significant downward effect on the rate of CO² increase would be a global recession. 
The 2007-8 crisis flattened the curve but in this case, it would have to be early in the year to have that outcome in 2020. In the absence of an economic downturn, business-as-usual would result in a figure straddling the 414 mark, with a tendency to be slightly over.
Another factor to take into consideration is the passing of a significant tipping point, which would increase the rate of CO² emmissions by an incalculable amount, but taking us over the 416 level.

I see two challenges with this question. First, predicting a series that displays a broad trend (upward sloping) but also cycles. The cycles seem to peak in early May and reach their minimum in late August. The cycles are very constant over time. The trend also seems pretty constant, but may be increasing as global warming becomes more and more of a problem.  I'm going to try twp different techniques to forecast this question and I'll explain them below. I begin with the simpler and get more complicated.  First pass: I look at just December 1 days, from 2009 - 2019, which ignores the effects of the cycles, but obviously decreases the precision of the forecast. That series increases by 2.4 on average, with larger increases of about 3 in recent years. Since last December 1st had a value of 411.46, it suggests a prediction that puts most of the weight in the 3rd bin, a bit in the second, and very little in the two extreme bins.  Second pass: Running a fixed effects regression, where we use year and month as factors. Essentially, the year factors should pick up the trend, while the months should pick up the cycles. When I run the regression over the whole sample I find evidence of this. Months 7 through 10 have negative coefficients, and the coefficients on years are increasing each year.  I then run this out of sample by using 2009 data to predict 2010, 2009 and 2010 data to predict 2011, etc. I find that month coefficients are pretty stable, and year coefficients increase around ~2.5 a year. This gives a point estimate of 414.33. I'm not really sure how to think of the distribution.  Essentially, this second pass is rerunning the first pass but incorporating more information than just data on December 1st.  Let me know what you think, if I'm missing anything, or any broad comments.
